text:
The **economy of Ivory Coast** is stable and currently growing, in the
aftermath of political instability in recent decades. The Ivory Coast's
economy is largely market-based and depends heavily on the agricultural
sector. Almost 70% of the Ivorian people are engaged in some form of
agricultural activity. The economy grew 82% in the 1960s, reaching a peak
growth of 360% in the 1970s, but this proved unsustainable and it shrank by
28% in the 1980s and a further 22% in the 1990s. This decline, coupled with
high population growth, resulted in a steady fall in living standards. The
gross national product per capita, now rising again, was about US$727 in 1996.
It was substantially higher two decades before. Real GDP growth is expected to
average 6.5% in 2024–25.

After several years of lagging performance, the Ivorian economy began a
comeback in 1994, due to the devaluation of the CFA franc and improved prices
for cocoa and coffee, growth in non-traditional primary exports such as
pineapples and rubber, limited trade and banking liberalization, offshore oil
and gas discoveries, and generous external financing and debt rescheduling by
multilateral lenders and France. The 50% devaluation of franc zone currencies
on 12 January 1994 caused a one-time jump in the inflation rate to 26% in
1994, but the rate fell sharply from 1996–1999. Moreover, government adherence
to donor-mandated reforms led to a jump in growth to 5% annually in 1996–99. A
majority of the population remains dependent on smallholder cash crop
production.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Ivory Coast is currently stable and experiencing growth following a period of political instability in recent decades.
• The Ivorian economy is predominantly market-based and relies heavily on the agricultural sector, with nearly 70% of the population engaged in some form of agricultural activity.
• During the 1960s, the economy grew by 82%, reaching a peak growth rate of 360% in the 1970s; however, this rapid expansion proved unsustainable.
• The economy contracted by 28% in the 1980s and a further 22% in the 1990s, leading to a decline in living standards and a decrease in gross national product (GNP) per capita.
• The GNP per capita was approximately US$727 in 1996, which was significantly higher two decades earlier.
• Real GDP growth is projected to average 6.5% during 2024–25.
• The Ivorian economy began a recovery in 1994 after several years of poor performance, driven by several key factors:
• Devaluation of the CFA franc, which improved export competitiveness.
• Increased prices for cocoa and coffee, two major traditional exports.
• Growth in non-traditional primary exports such as pineapples and rubber.
• Limited liberalization of trade and banking sectors.
• Discoveries of offshore oil and gas reserves.
• Generous external financing and debt rescheduling provided by multilateral lenders and France.
• On 12 January 1994, the CFA franc was devalued by 50%, which caused a temporary spike in inflation to 26% in 1994.
• The inflation rate declined sharply from 1996 to 1999.
• Government adherence to reforms mandated by international donors contributed to an increase in annual growth to 5% during 1996–99.
• A significant portion of the population remains dependent on smallholder cash crop production for their livelihood.

text:
By developing-country standards, Ivory Coast has an outstanding
infrastructure. There is a network of more than 13,000 kilometres (8,000 mi)
of paved roads; modern telecommunications services, including a public data
communications network; cellular phones and Internet access; two active ports,
one of which, Abidjan, is the most modern in West Africa; rail links-in the
process of being upgraded-both within the country and to Burkina Faso; regular
air service within the region and to and from Europe; and real estate
developments for commercial, industrial, retail, and residential use. Ivory
Coast's location and connections to neighboring countries makes it a preferred
platform for foreigners to conduct West African business operations. The city
of Abidjan is one of the most modern and liveable cities in the region.

The government's public investment plan accords priority to investment in
human capital, and to provide for significant spending on the economic
infrastructure needed to sustain growth.

In the new environment of government disengagement from productive activities
and in the wake of recent privatizations, anticipated investments in the
petroleum, electricity, water, and telecommunications sectors, and in part of
the transport sector, will be financed without any direct government
intervention.

Mean wages were $1.05 per man-hour in 2009.
openai_summarised_points: • Ivory Coast possesses an advanced infrastructure relative to developing-country standards, reflecting significant development efforts.
• The country has a network of over 13,000 kilometers (8,000 miles) of paved roads, facilitating domestic transportation and connectivity.
• Modern telecommunications services are available, including a public data communications network, cellular phone services, and Internet access, supporting communication and digital connectivity.
• Ivory Coast maintains two active ports, with the port of Abidjan being the most modern port in West Africa, serving as a key maritime hub for regional trade.
• The rail network is undergoing upgrades to improve transportation efficiency both within Ivory Coast and to neighboring Burkina Faso, enhancing regional connectivity.
• The country offers regular air services within West Africa and to Europe, supporting regional and international mobility.
• There are ongoing real estate developments across various sectors, including commercial, industrial, retail, and residential properties, indicating economic growth and urban development.
• Ivory Coast's strategic location and strong regional connections make it a preferred platform for foreign businesses operating in West Africa.
• The city of Abidjan is recognized as one of the most modern and livable cities in the West African region, reflecting urban development and infrastructure quality.
• The government’s public investment plan prioritizes investment in human capital and allocates substantial spending toward economic infrastructure to sustain economic growth.

• Following a period of government disengagement from productive activities and recent privatizations, future investments in sectors such as petroleum, electricity, water, telecommunications, and parts of the transport sector are expected to be financed without direct government intervention.
• In 2009, the average wages were approximately $1.05 per man-hour, indicating the wage level within the country's labor market.

text:
Ivory Coast produced, in 2018:

* 7.2 million tonnes of yam (3rd largest producer in the world, only behind Nigeria and Ghana)
* 5 million tons of cassava (14th largest producer in the world)
* 2.1 million tons of palm oil
* 2.1 million tons of rice
* 1.9 million tons of cocoa (largest producer in the world)
* 1.9 million tons of sugar cane
* 1.8 million tons of plantain (8th largest producer in the world)
* 1 million tons of maize
* 688 thousand tons of cashew nuts (3rd largest producer in the world, behind Vietnam and India)
* 461 thousand tons of natural rubber
* 397 thousand tons of banana
* 316 thousand tons of cotton

This is in addition to smaller productions of other agricultural products,
like coffee (88 thousand tons) and pineapple (50 thousand tons).

Ivory Coast is among the world's largest producers and exporters of cocoa
beans and palm oil. Consequently, the economy is highly sensitive to
fluctuations in international prices for these products and to weather
conditions. Despite attempts by the government to diversify the economy, it is
still largely dependent on agriculture and related activities. Forced labor by
children bought and sold as slaves are endemic in cacao production.
openai_summarised_points: • In 2018, Ivory Coast produced approximately 7.2 million tonnes of yam, ranking as the third-largest producer globally, behind Nigeria and Ghana.
• The country produced around 5 million tonnes of cassava, making it the 14th largest producer in the world.
• Ivory Coast's palm oil production reached approximately 2.1 million tonnes in 2018.
• The nation produced about 2.1 million tonnes of rice during the same year.
• It was the world's largest producer of cocoa, with an output of approximately 1.9 million tonnes in 2018.
• Ivory Coast produced roughly 1.9 million tonnes of sugar cane in 2018.
• The country was the 8th largest producer of plantain globally, with a production of about 1.8 million tonnes.
• Maize production in Ivory Coast amounted to approximately 1 million tonnes in 2018.
• Cashew nut production was around 688 thousand tonnes, making Ivory Coast the third-largest producer worldwide, after Vietnam and India.
• The country produced approximately 461 thousand tonnes of natural rubber in 2018.
• Banana production reached about 397 thousand tonnes.
• Cotton production was approximately 316 thousand tonnes.
• Additional smaller-scale productions included coffee (88 thousand tonnes) and pineapple (50 thousand tonnes).
• Ivory Coast is among the world's leading producers and exporters of cocoa beans and palm oil.
• The economy is highly sensitive to fluctuations in international prices for cocoa and palm oil, as well as to weather conditions.
• Despite government efforts to diversify the economy, it remains predominantly dependent on agriculture and related activities.
• Forced child labor, involving children bought and sold as slaves, is endemic in cocoa production in Ivory Coast.

text:
Côte d'Ivoire's energy supply relies on several hydroelectric stations and
gas-to-power plants that make use of the country's hydraulic and natural gas
resources. Over recent years, the country has also sought to develop its solar
industry and is setting up several solar PV plants to diversify its energy
mix.

Côte d'Ivoire also holds oil and natural gas resources offshore, though
production has remained small compared to other African neighbours such as
Ghana or Nigeria. For example, in 2021, it only produced about 25,000 barrels
of oil per day.

Since 2021, the Italian energy company Eni has made multiple oil and gas
discoveries in the offshore Baleine Field and begun their development. In
December 2024, its production facilities there entered their second phase,
generating 70m cubic feet of gas and 60,000 barrels of oil per day.
openai_summarised_points: • Côte d'Ivoire's energy supply primarily depends on hydroelectric stations and gas-to-power plants that utilize the country's hydraulic and natural gas resources.
• The country has been actively developing its solar energy sector by establishing several solar photovoltaic (PV) plants to diversify its energy mix.
• Côte d'Ivoire possesses offshore oil and natural gas reserves; however, its production levels remain modest compared to neighboring African countries such as Ghana and Nigeria.
• In 2021, Côte d'Ivoire produced approximately 25,000 barrels of oil per day, indicating relatively small-scale oil output.
• Since 2021, the Italian energy company Eni has made multiple discoveries of oil and gas in the offshore Baleine Field.
• Eni has initiated development activities in the Baleine Field, and by December 2024, its production facilities entered their second phase.
• The second phase of development at Baleine Field's facilities is expected to generate 70 million cubic feet of gas and 60,000 barrels of oil per day.

text:
In 2019, the country was the 9th largest world producer of manganese.

In the production of gold, in 2017 the country produced 20.3 tons.
openai_summarised_points: • In 2019, Ivory Coast was the 9th largest producer of manganese globally, highlighting its significant role in the international manganese market.
• The country's manganese production contributed substantially to its mineral export revenues and economic development.
• In the gold sector, Ivory Coast produced 20.3 tons of gold in the year 2017, indicating its active participation in gold mining activities.
• Gold production data from 2017 reflects the country's ongoing engagement in gold extraction, which is a key component of its mineral industry.
• The information underscores Ivory Coast's position as a notable player in the global mineral resource landscape, particularly in manganese and gold.

text:
Ivory Coast has emerged as a significant player in the global rubber market.
In 2022, the nation produced 1.55 million tonnes of natural rubber, surpassing
Vietnam to become the world's third-largest producer. This significant
increase from 815,000 tonnes in 2019 can be attributed to several factors,
including a shift by Ivorian farmers from cacao to rubber cultivation. This
shift is driven by the potential benefits of European sustainability
regulations, which will take effect in 2025.
openai_summarised_points: • Ivory Coast has become a notable participant in the global rubber market, indicating its growing importance in this sector.
• In 2022, Ivory Coast produced 1.55 million tonnes of natural rubber, establishing itself as the world's third-largest producer of natural rubber.
• This production figure in 2022 surpassed Vietnam, which was previously one of the leading producers, highlighting Ivory Coast's rapid growth in rubber output.
• The country's rubber production significantly increased from 815,000 tonnes in 2019, reflecting a substantial growth trajectory over three years.
• The increase in rubber production is primarily attributed to a shift by Ivorian farmers from cacao cultivation to rubber cultivation.
• The shift in agricultural focus is motivated by the potential benefits associated with upcoming European sustainability regulations, which are scheduled to take effect in 2025.

text:
Hotel Ivoire in Abidjan includes a casino.

Ivory Coast has made progress in diversifying its economy, and since the
1970s, has steadily expanded the facilities offered to tourists. Resort
lodgings in coastal areas have been developed. There are numerous hotels in
Abidjan, including international chains such as Novotel and Sofitel.
openai_summarised_points: • The Hotel Ivoire in Abidjan features a casino, serving as a notable hospitality establishment within the country's tourism infrastructure.
• Ivory Coast has made significant progress in diversifying its economy, reducing reliance on traditional sectors.
• Since the 1970s, the country has steadily expanded its tourism facilities, indicating a sustained effort to develop the sector.
• Coastal areas have seen the development of resort lodgings, aimed at attracting tourists seeking leisure and recreational activities.

• Abidjan, the economic capital, hosts numerous hotels, including internationally recognized hotel chains such as Novotel and Sofitel, highlighting the country's integration into global tourism networks.

text:
Ivoirian exports in 2006

Foreign direct investment (FDI) plays a key role in the Ivorian economy,
accounting for between 40% and 45% of total capital in Ivorian firms. France
is overwhelmingly the most important foreign investor. In recent
years[_when?_], French investment has accounted for about one-quarter of the
total capital in Ivorian enterprises, and between 55% and 60% of the total
stock of foreign investment capital.

The stock market capitalisation of listed companies in Ivory Coast was $2,327
million in 2005 by the World Bank.

In March 2025, Côte d'Ivoire was scheduled to carry out its first bond issue
in CFA Francs on the international market.
